* Simplified point 5: A notice of intended entry under this section may not be served after the end of the period of three years (for compulsory purchase orders) or five years (in any other case) beginning with the day on which the authorising instrument becomes operative.
* Simplified point 1: The owner of land can limit the amount of time the government has to take temporary possession of their property through a counter-notice.
* Simplified point 2: If the owner falls within certain categories (leasehold interest, right to occupy, or freehold interest), they have different options for how long the government can take temporary possession of their land.
* Simplified point 3: The owner can choose to either accept the counter-notice, withdraw the notice of intended entry, or proceed as if the land were subject to compulsory acquisition.
* Simplified point 4: If the acquiring authority decides to proceed with compulsory acquisition, the instrument authorizing temporary possession will be treated as authorization for compulsory acquisition, and the authority may proceed as if it had given the necessary notices.
* Simplified point 1: The section of the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965 that deals with refusing to give up possession of land is applied to temporary possession under the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017.
* Simplified point 2: This means that if someone is temporarily possessing land through the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017, they cannot be forced to give up possession without going through the legal process outlined in the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965.
* Simplified point 3: Specifically, the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965 gives the acquiring authority the power to take possession of land compulsorily, but only after following certain legal procedures and obtaining the necessary approvals.
* Simplified point 1: The government can take possession of private land temporarily for development projects, but they must provide compensation to the landowner for any losses incurred.
* Simplified point 2: The amount of compensation is calculated based on the length of time the land is taken, the value of the land, and any losses incurred by the landowner due to the temporary possession.
* Simplified point 3: If the landowner is running a business on the land, they are also entitled to compensation for the disruption of their trade or business.
* Simplified point 4: The compensation amount includes interest from the day after the last day of the period of temporary possession, and any disputes about compensation can be referred to the Upper Tribunal.
* Simplified point 1: The government can make advance payments to people who will lose land due to a development project, to help them cover costs while they wait for final compensation.
* Simplified point 2: To receive an advance payment, the person must request it in writing and provide information about their entitlement to compensation. The government then has 28 days to determine if they have enough information to make the payment. If they need more info, they can ask the claimant for it.
* Simplified point 3: Advance payments are based on the government's estimate of the compensation amount, but if their estimate is too low, they will pay the difference later.
* Simplified point 4: If the total advance payment exceeds the final compensation amount, the excess must be repaid. If someone receives an advance payment they weren't entitled to, they must repay it.
* Simplified point 1: The local council must pay interest if they don't pay compensation within the time frame set out in the law.
* Simplified point 2: If the council overpays compensation, they can reclaim the interest paid.
* Simplified point 3: The government sets the interest rate.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations can add more details about how interest is paid.
* Simplified point 1: The Town and Country Planning Act 1990 is amended to include new provisions related to temporary possession of land.
* Simplified point 2: Paragraph 24A of Schedule 13 is added to the Act, allowing for the temporary possession of land that is blighted due to planning proposals by public authorities.
* Simplified point 3: Section 150 of the Act is amended to include the new provision for temporary possession of land, and section 151 is amended to reflect the changes made to section 150.
* Simplified point 4: Section 155 of the Act is amended to clarify the effect of counter-notices on the power of compulsory acquisition, and section 169 is amended to define "appropriate authority" in relation to blighted land.
* Simplified point 5: Section 170 of the Act is amended to define "appropriate enactment" in relation to blighted land, and section 172 of the Housing and Planning Act 2016 is amended to include the new provision for temporary possession of land.

series.short: Neighbourhood Planning Act Modifications to Land Compensation Act: No-Scheme Principle and Dispute Resolution
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 modifies the Land Compensation Act 1961 regarding the "no-scheme" principle.
* Simplified point 2: The "no-scheme" principle applies to four scenarios: (i) cancellation of the scheme on the valuation date, (ii) absence of any other projects, (iii) absence of prospects of the same or similar schemes, and (iv) assumption that no other projects would have been undertaken if the scheme had been canceled.
* Simplified point 3: If the original land is subject to compulsory acquisition, and the person has an interest in other land that increases in value due to the scheme, the amount of compensation to which the person is entitled is reduced by the amount of the increase in value.
* Simplified point 4: If part of the other land is subject to compulsory acquisition, the compensation to which the person is entitled is reduced accordingly.
* Simplified point 5: Sections 6A, 6B, and 6C of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 outline the "no-scheme" principle's application to various situations, including compulsory acquisitions for highways and urban development areas.
* Simplified point 6: Section 6D of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 specifies the "underlying scheme" for the purpose of identifying the no-scheme principle. It allows for disputes over the identification of the underlying scheme to be resolved by the Upper Tribunal.
* Simplified point 7: Section 6E of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 provides additional provisions related to relevant transport projects, specifically regeneration or redevelopment facilitated or enabled by such projects.

* Simplified point 1: The Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 alters the Land Compensation Act 1961 regarding the "no-scheme" concept.
* Simplified point 2: Under the "no-scheme" idea, four circumstances are considered: (i) the cancellation of the program on the valuation date, (ii) the lack of other initiatives, (iii) the lack of prospects for comparable programs, and (iv) the presumption that no other initiatives would have been implemented if the program had been cancelled.
* Simplified point 3: If the initial land is subject to compulsory acquisition and the individual has an interest in other land whose value rises because of the program, the amount of compensation to which the person is entitled is decreased by the amount of the rise in value.
* Simplified point 4: If some of the other land is subject to compulsory acquisition, the compensation to which the person is entitled is reduced accordingly.
* Simplified point 5: Sections 6A, 6B, and 6C of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 describe how the "no-scheme" rule applies to various situations, including compulsory purchases for highways and urban development areas.
* Simplified point 6: Section 6D of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 defines the "underlying scheme" for determining the no-scheme principle, allowing disagreements over its identification to be settled by the Upper Tribunal.
* Simplified point 7: Section 6E of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 offers extra rules for significant transport projects, particularly those that aid or enable regeneration or redevelopment.

summary: In simple terms, the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017 is a law that helps communities shape their future by giving them more control over planning decisions. It requires local authorities to consider neighborhood development plans when making decisions about planning applications. The law also allows for the modification of existing neighborhood development orders and plans without needing to go through a full review process, as long as the modifications do not materially affect any planning permissions granted by the order. Additionally, the law empowers the Secretary of State to issue guidance on how local planning authorities should address housing needs resulting from aging or disability. Finally, the law provides for the temporary possession of land for development projects, with strict regulations and compensation for landowners.
